values.text: The 14 day period begins with Day 1 on the day of entry into Thailand, not the day of departure from the high-risk area.

dialog_nodes.title: How long does the virus last?

values.text: Symptoms for Covid-19 typically appear 2-14 days after contracting the virus. You should contact your healthcare professional at the first sign of symptoms.

Everyone must stay at home to help stop the spread of coronavirus. You should keep yourself clean and wash your hand regularly especially after you've got contact to object that might be contaminated.
You should only leave the house for 1 of 4 reasons:
- shopping for basic necessities, for example food and medicine, which must be as infrequent as possible
- one form of exercise a day, for example a run, walk, or cycle – alone or with members of your household
- any medical need, or to provide care or to help a vulnerable person
- travelling to and from work, but only where this absolutely cannot be done from home

International travellers:

- Only travellers with a valid passport will be able to access the international terminal.
-To help with social distancing requirements we also request that travellers only arrive three hours before their flight.

Domestic travellers

-The domestic terminal is still open however; the Government has asked to limit all non-essential domestic travel. People are encouraged not to visit different parts of the country unless it’s for an essential reason.

dialog_nodes.title: Can I return to the United States?

values.text:
If you are returning to the US from international travel, the CDC recommends following these guidelines.
Information for Visa Applicants Regarding Novel Coronavirus read more. Stay home for 14 days from the time you returned from international travel. During this 14-day period, take these steps to monitor your health and practice social distancing:
-Take your temperature with a thermometer two times a day and monitor for fever. Also watch for cough or trouble breathing. -Stay home and avoid contact with others. Do not go to work or school. -Do not take public transportation, taxis, or ride-shares. -Keep your distance from others (about 6 feet or 2 meters).
For more information on travel restrictions, visit here.
All those who live in the same household will need to complete a travel declaration form if they are travelling overseas

During this 14 day self quarantine period, we advise you to follow the government guidance to minimise contact with people and stay away from busy places such as public transport and shopping centres. As far as possible, avoid face to face contact with anyone from community.
Find our Covid-19 alert document: click here to find our more

Social distancing generally means remaining and managing a minimum of six feet of separation between people. 

Keeping this distance helps prevent droplets created by sneezing and coughing from reaching you.

There are other actions - like washing your hands with soap frequently, you can take to reduce the risk of possible exposure in the community. Would you like to hear more?
Yes. A person who had made transits in airports located in high-risk countries/areas will need to be quarantined for 14 days upon arrival in Thailand.

FYI, If you are returning from an area with widespread, ongoing community spread (Level 3 Travel Health Notice countries), stay home for 14 days from the time you left and practice social distancing. See the latest the CDC Travel Health Notices here: here Depending on your unique circumstances, you may choose to delay or cancel your plans. If you do decide to travel, be sure to practice precautions to prevent getting and spreading COVID-19 and other respiratory diseases during travel. For the most up-to-date COVID-19 travel information, visit CDC COVID-19 Travel page:

dialog_nodes.title: I am currently traveling out of the country. Who should I contact?

values.text:
Follow the Geographic Risk Assessment map for COVID-19 transmission here.
You can also find a list of State and Local Health Departments here.
Watch this video from the World Health Organization to learn what we know about COVID-19 right now: click here to find our more

There are things you can do to help reduce the risk of you and anyone you live with getting ill with coronavirus.

Do
-  wash your hands with soap and water often – do this for at least 20 seconds
-  use hand sanitiser gel if soap and water are not available
-  wash your hands as soon as you get back home
-  cover your mouth and nose with a tissue or your sleeve (not your hands) when you cough or sneeze
-  put used tissues in the bin immediately and wash your hands afterwards

Don't
-  do not touch your eyes, nose or mouth if your hands are not clean

The CDC recommends washing your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, being sure to scrub all around and under fingernails, and finally drying with an air dryer or clean towel. If you do not have access to soap or running water, you can use a hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol concentration. You can find more information on the CDC's hand-washing recommendations here. Protect yourself. Clean your hands regularly. Wash your hands with soap and water, and dry them thoroughly: click here to find our more
For the latest coronavirus curfew update in Thailand:
From ThaiPBS: available here
From BangkokPost: available here

dialog_nodes.title: Do I need to get tested?

values.text:
Not everyone needs to be tested for COVID-19.
The process and locations for testing vary from place to place. Contact your state, local, tribal, or territorial department for more information, or reach out to a medical provider. For more information about testing, see the CDC's guidelines on Testing for COVID-19 .
You can find a list of State and Local Health Departments here.
If you develop emergency warning signs for COVID-19 get medical attention immediately. Emergency warning signs include*:
-Trouble breathing -Persistent pain or pressure in the chest -New confusion or inability to arouse -Bluish lips or face
*This list is not all inclusive. Please consult your medical provider for any other symptoms that are severe or concerning.
For more information visit here.

dialog_nodes.title: What countries are high risk to travel to?

values.text: Follow the CDC's guidelines for all travel. You can find travel recommendations by country as well as a Geographic Risk Assessment map for COVID-19 transmission here.
Travel information from Thailand Embassy: available here

The best way to protect yourself, family, friends and colleagues from germs and viruses is to wash your hands for 20 seconds with soap and water and dry them well.

So, whether you’re at work or at home:

1. Wet your hands under clean running water. Use warm water if available.
2. Put soap on your hands and wash for 20 seconds. Liquid soap is best.
3. Rub hands together until the soap makes bubbles.
4. Rub on both sides of both hands ...
5. and in between fingers and thumbs ...
6. and round and round both hands.
7. Rinse all the soap off under clean running water. Use warm water if available.
8. Dry your hands all over for 20 seconds. Using a paper towel is best (or, if at home, a clean dry towel)

Always wash and dry your hands ...

Before
-  Eating or preparing food.

After
-  Sneezing, coughing or blowing your nose (or wiping children's noses)
-  Gardening (or playing outside for children)
-  Having contact with animals
-  Going to the toilet or changing nappies
-  Looking after sick people

Yes. Please refer to the following directive issued by the Ministry of Education of Thailand on February 28, 2020.

“In case that the government officers, teachers and educational personnel, officers under the Ministry of Education and all divisions, students in all schools and universities under the Ministry of Education have family members returned from at-risk countries or have had close contact with those who are suspected to be an infected case, they must not attend class or not go to work for 14-day self-quarantine at home.” 

With effect from February 28th, 2020, any personnel which falls under the directive above will need to be quarantined for 14 days.

To date, there is no vaccine and no specific antiviral medicine to prevent or treat COVID-2019. However, those affected should receive care to relieve symptoms. People with serious illness should be hospitalized. Most patients recover thanks to supportive care.
Possible vaccines and some specific drug treatments are under investigation. They are being tested through clinical trials. WHO is coordinating efforts to develop vaccines and medicines to prevent and treat COVID-19.
The most effective ways to protect yourself and others against COVID-19 are to frequently clean your hands, cover your cough with the bend of elbow or tissue, and maintain a distance of at least 1 meter (3 feet) from people who are coughing or sneezing. For more information visit the World Heath Organization's website.

If you need medical help for any reason, do not go to places like a GP surgery, pharmacy or hospital.

If you have symptoms of coronavirus (a high temperature or a new, continuous cough), use the 111 coronavirus service.

If you need help or advice not related to coronavirus:
-  for health information and advice, use the NHS website or your GP surgery website
-  for urgent medical help, use the NHS 111 online service – only call 111 if you're unable to get help online
-  for life-threatening emergencies, call 999 for an ambulance

Read more advice about getting medical help at home.

The most common symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, a dry cough, and shortness of breath. These symptoms may appear 2-14 days after exposure. Call your doctor: If you think you have been exposed to COVID-19 and develop a fever and symptoms, such as cough or difficulty breathing, call your healthcare provider for medical advice. If you develop emergency warning signs for COVID-19 get medical attention immediately. Emergency warning signs include: -Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath -Persistent pain or pressure in the chest -New confusion or inability to arouse -Bluish lips or face For more information, visit: https://ibm.biz/BdqfkZ

dialog_nodes.title: Ministry of Education of Thailand Quarantine Guildline

values.text: According to the directive by the Ministry of Education of Thailand, all residents who live in the same household must be placed on a 14-day quarantine starting from the day of arrival to Thailand, if they have visited the following high-risk countries/areas: China, Macau, Japan, Hong Kong, South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore, Iran, Italy, France, Germany and Spain.
Based on WHO guideline, standard medical grade mask can significantly reduce infection rate. However, there is a lot more to that. Please read WHO guideline for this click here to find our more

dialog_nodes.title: What does a national emergency mean?

values.text: Due to the ongoing impact of coronavirus/COVID-19. Visit US Embassy in Thailand webpages on COVID-19 for information on conditions.
There is currently no reported infection from swimming in the pool. Or other water sources But should avoid a crowded pool
If you're pregnant and worried about coronavirus, you can get advice about coronavirus and pregnancy from the Royal College of Obstretricians and Gynaecologists.

Please do not discuss anyone you have concerns about via any type of social media. This can be damaging to the community and people’s wellbeing and has no positive outcomes. Many people may have a range of health issues that are in no way related to a risk of Covid-19.

Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) & Department of Disease Control recommends for your safety and for others, and to decrease negative social and economic impacts. The Disease Infected Zones were determined to include the People’s Republic of China (including Special Administrative Regions Macau and Hong Kong), South Korea, Iran and Italy: click here to find our more

Ministry of Public Health By the Department of Disease Control There are suggestions for those traveling to or from abroad. Publish on website https://ibm.biz/Bdqfk2 When traveling back from a country that has an ongoing epidemic The Ministry of Public Health recommends refraining from going out in public places unnecessarily. And measure body temperature daily until 14 days have elapsed after traveling to Thailand During the symptom observation, if there is a fever, cough, report 1422.
No. Anyone who had travelled to high-risk countries/areas should be quarantined for 14 days and should not visit the school premises.

dialog_nodes.title: How can I prevent getting Covid-19?

values.text: Covid-19 is thought to spread mainly through person to person transmission, so it's important to distance yourself from others as much as possible to prevent getting the virus. Additionally, you should wash your hands often and avoid touching your face as much as possible. For more information, check out the CDC's guide to protecting yourself and others.

There is a study report in China. The infection was detected by RT-PCR again after receiving treatment and no infection was found at least 2 times apart, 48 hours apart. However, more studies have yet to be found that the positive RT-PCR results Means the patient is infected because RT-PCR is a test that does not indicate infection. In addition, patients who have detected the infection do not show symptoms. In general, general viral infection Patients who recover from the disease build immunity that is high enough to prevent the disease for many months.

In February 2020, China has approved the use of Favilavir for the treatment of COVID-19.Also, many drugs such as antiretroviral therapy (lopinavir with Ritonavir) are used in combination with anti-influenza, anti-malarial drugs. Remdesivir has been found to be effective in vitro and in animals infected with SARS and MERS. All of this still requires further research to confirm reliable treatment results. For treatment, it is advisable to only be hospitalized by a professional doctor. To fully achieve therapeutic effects and prevent dangerous side effects from medication

If you have fever, cough, or shortness of breath, call your healthcare provider. They may tell you to manage your care from home. If so, follow these tips.
If you develop emergency warning signs for COVID-19 get medical attention immediately. Emergency warning signs include*:
-Trouble breathing -Persistent pain or pressure in the chest -New confusion or inability to arouse -Bluish lips or face *This list is not all inclusive. Please consult your medical provider for any other symptoms that are severe or concerning.
For more information on caring for yourself at home, visit here.
Look here to find out about getting tested for COVID-19 in Thailand: click here to find our more

Herbal medicine such as andrographis paniculata can andrographis paniculata, an herbal medicine recommended by the Department of Thai Traditional Medicine and Alternative Medicine to treat colds. And to eat immediately. COVID-19 is a virus in the corona virus group. Not influenza virus There has never been a blue sky robber to try to treat COVID-19 to cure coronary disease or not.

Call your doctor: If you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19 or you are a resident in a community where there is ongoing spread of COVID-19 and develop symptoms of COVID-19, call your healthcare provider and tell them about your symptoms and your exposure. They will decide whether you need to be tested, but keep in mind that there is no treatment for COVID-19 and people who are mildly ill may be able to isolate and care for themselves at home. Thailand Hospital is offering screening tests for anyone in Thailand who suspects they are showing symptoms of the corona virus:
COVID-19 hospital in Thailand: click here to find our more
A pandemic is an outbreak that has spread globally and can not be easily tracked or contained.  The CDC has more information on why Covid-19 is a pandemic and what that means on their web site.

To help yourself stay well while you're at home:

-  stay in touch with family and friends over the phone or on social media
-  try to keep yourself busy – you could try activities like cooking, reading, online learning and watching films
-  do light exercise at home, or outside once a day

dialog_nodes.title: What happens when the hospital is full?

values.text:
Listen to and follow the directions of your state and local authorities.
Not all patients with COVID-19 require hospital admission. Patients whose clinical presentation warrants in-patient clinical management for supportive medical care should be admitted to the hospital under appropriate isolation precautions.
The decision to monitor these patients in the inpatient or outpatient setting should be made on a case-by-case basis. This decision will depend not only on the clinical presentation, but also on the patient’s ability to engage in self-monitoring, the feasibility of safe isolation at home, and the risk of transmission in the patient’s home environment.
For more information visit here or here .
Know the facts about coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and help stop the spread of rumors.
click here to find our more

From Tuesday 24 March, parents are encouraged to keep their children at home. No child will be turned away from school.

Any student or staff member who over the last 14 days has been overseas should be in self-isolation for 14 days after they returned. They are excluded from school and should not return to school or child care services for a period of 14 days after arriving, as the COVID-19 incubation period can be as long as two weeks.

Staff and students who have been identified as close contacts of a person diagnosed with COVID-19 during their infectious period must also self-isolate at home, and should not attend school or childcare settings until 14 days after their last contact with the infected person.

dialog_nodes.title: Should I wear a mask in public?

values.text: The CDC recommends wearing a cloth face covering in public settings where social distancing may be difficult to maintain. For more information on face coverings and general guidance on protecting yourself and others please visit the CDC web site. Healthcare workers caring for patients suspected to have Covid-19 also need to wear face-masks to prevent additional spread of Covid-19. If you have a surplus of N95 masks or surgical masks, consider donating them to a local hospital.

dialog_nodes.title: Are there any travel restrictions in place yet?

values.text: Follow the CDC's guidelines for all travel. You can find travel restrictions by country as well as a Geographic Risk Assessment map for COVID-19 transmission here.

dialog_nodes.title: Everything you need to prep for home quarantine

values.text:
CASE STUDY

Family member/resident/visitor arrives in Thailand on Feb 28th, 2020, from a high-risk country/area. Family member/resident/visitor who had travelled to high-risk country/area, and child (did not travel) both need to be quarantined for 14 days, even though no one has tested positive for COVID-19. Feb 28th, 2020 is counted as the first day of quarantine.

dialog_nodes.title: Covid Thailand - Introduces tough entry restrictions

values.text: The Royal Thai Government (RTG) has implemented enhanced screening and quarantine measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19.  Travelers should be prepared for travel restrictions to be put into effect with little or no advance notice.  U.S. citizens who are considering returning to the United States are urged to work with their airlines to make travel arrangements while flights are still available.

Today, the Civil Aviation Authority of Thailand (CAAT) announced the extension until 30 April 2020 of the ban on incoming international flights. The extension will likely mean a further reduction in outgoing international flights in the days ahead read more

COVID-19 can spread through contaminated items. Can last for many days without cleaning For example, various devices Used in public areas such as door knobs and door handles, faucets, handrails, public vehicles, etc. In addition, there may be tarnish through the hand and then hold the mobile phone If using hands to touch an object and then touch the face area Or picking food into the mouth Can be infected as well as direct contact from patients. dialog_nodes.title: The costs of testing for COVID-19 infection

values.text: Call your doctor: If you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19 or you are a resident in a community where there is ongoing spread of COVID-19 and develop symptoms of COVID-19, call your healthcare provider and tell them about your symptoms and your exposure. They will decide whether you need to be tested, but keep in mind that there is no treatment for COVID-19 and people who are mildly ill may be able to isolate and care for themselves at home. According to information obtained by Thai PBS, the charges made for an individual to be tested for COVID-19 infection vary from hospital to hospital available here
Shortness of breath refers to difficulty breathing. The Mayo clinic has a definition here.

On 7 April 2020, the Ministry of Digital Economy and Society, in cooperation with Digital Economy Promotion Agency (DEPA), IBM, and Ecartstudio, launched a new mobile application called “Card2U,” which provides real time information on COVID-19. This mobile application offers updated official information to help the public cope with the COVID-19 outbreak, such as, infected areas, risk assessment before testing, lists of hospital for COVID-19 examination, hotlines, etc. The application is now available for download from the Apple App Store and Play Store. All new users are required to register for a digital card which is needed for access to the latest news and services related to COVID-19. click here to find our more

If your temperature is 38 degrees or higher, please stay at home and seek medical advice. If your temperature becomes elevated in school, the necessary arrangements will be made to have you sent home safely.

If you have not travelled to the high risk areas, you will be able to return to school when you are fully recovered and are able to bring a note of good health from a reputable doctor.

Please remember that a high temperature may be a symptom of a number of illnesses, there is no reason to assume that a temperature is caused by the Covid-19 virus.

Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses, some causing illness in people and others circulating among animals, including camels, cats and bats.

The 2019 novel coronavirus (COVID-19) is a new virus that causes respiratory illness in people and can spread from person-to-person. This virus was first identified during an investigation into an outbreak in Wuhan, China.

The name of this disease is coronavirus disease 2019, abbreviated as COVID-19. In COVID-19, ‘CO’ stands for ‘corona,’ ‘VI’ for ‘virus,’ and ‘D’ for disease. Formerly, this disease was referred to as “2019 novel coronavirus” or “2019-nCoV.”

There is currently no strong evidence of the transmission as airborne. values.text: Common symptoms can vary from person to person. This information is intended to provide personal guidance. Only your doctor can make a complete diagnosis. Seek immediate medical attention for any serious or life threatening health issue.
Someone with coronavirus would typically have a fever.
The CDC considers a person to have a fever when he or she has a measured temperature of 100.4° F (38° C) or greater, or feels warm to the touch, or gives a history of feeling feverish.
Fever is one of the symptoms of the corona virus.

Seasonal allergies cause sneezing, coughing, runny nose and irritated skin or eyes while COVID-19 can be mild but can include fever, body aches and difficulty breathing. COVID-19 or the flu come on quickly while allergies are mitigated by limiting exposure (not going outside).

Seasonal allergies, also known as allergic rhinitis or hay fever, are an immune response to pollen and mold. Unlike a cold or the flu, allergy symptoms often last for several weeks to months of the years.  Allergies can also be an underlying cause of frequent sinus, ear, and respiratory infections. Symptoms include:
•	Sinus Congestion
•	Runny Nose
•	Post-Nasal Drip
•	Sneezing
•	Coughing
•	Itchy or Watery Eyes

dialog_nodes.title: What to do if you are sick

values.text: Call your doctor or schedule a virtual visit with a medical professional. Given heightened threat of coronavirus and the stress on the healthcare system, do not go to a doctor’s office, urgent care center or hospital emergency department without calling first.

dialog_nodes.title: Steps to help prevent the spread of COVID-19

values.text:
If you are sick with COVID-19 or suspect you are infected with the virus that causes COVID-19, follow the steps below to help prevent the disease from spreading to people in your home and community:
•	Stay home except to get medical care
•	Separate yourself from other people and animals in your home
•	Call ahead before visiting your doctor
•	Wear a face mask if you are sick
•	Clean your hands often
•	Clean all "high touch" surfaces everyday

COVID-19 causes a respiratory illness manifested by fever, cough and difficulty breathing. Those three symptoms together are indications of COVID-19. However, COVID-19 infection can also produce symptoms similar to the flu like aches and pains, sore throat, runny nose, nasal congestion or diarrhea.

values: What type of school do your children attend?

values.text: All schools below the college/university level in zip code $zip_code will remain closed until further notice.
Colleges and universities in zip code $zip_code have moved their classes online. Please contact your school for further details.

The symptoms of flu can include fever or feeling feverish/chills, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, muscle or body aches, headaches and fatigue (tiredness). Cold symptoms are usually milder than the symptoms of flu. People with colds are more likely to have a runny or stuffy nose. Colds generally do not result in serious health problems.

The symptoms of flu can include fever or feeling feverish/chills, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, muscle or body aches, headaches and fatigue (tiredness). However, COVID-19 causes a respiratory illness manifested by fever, cough and difficulty breathing. Those three symptoms together are indications of COVID-19. However, COVID-19 infection can also produce symptoms similar to the flu like aches and pains, sore throat, runny nose, nasal congestion or diarrhea.
Influenza (also known as “flu”) is a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses. It can cause mild to severe illness, and at times can lead to death.

Flu signs and symptoms usually come on suddenly. People who are sick with flu often feel some or all of these symptoms:
•	Fever* or feeling feverish/chills
•	Cough
•	Sore throat
•	Runny or stuffy nose
•	Muscle or body aches
•	Headaches
•	Fatigue (tiredness)
•	Some people may have vomiting and diarrhea, though this is more common in children than adults.

values.text: The common cold can present with symptoms that are similar to COVID-19 that include fatigue, sore throat, cough and runny nose and possibly a low-grade fever. However, COVID-19 while sometimes presenting with similar symptoms causes high fever, cough and difficulty breathing.

The symptoms of flu can include fever or feeling feverish/chills, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, muscle or body aches, headaches and fatigue (tiredness). Cold symptoms are usually milder than the symptoms of flu. People with colds are more likely to have a runny or stuffy nose. Colds generally do not result in serious health problems.

While you can certainly call your primary physician for advice and guidance the nominal cold will not require a doctor visit unless secondary indications require a visit – for example, if you contract a sinus infection or begin to have more severe breathing issues or lung and chest pains. Because the common cold is a virus, antibiotics won’t help. But over-the-counter medications may make you feel better.

If it’s a cold virus, you may find yourself close to a tissue box for several days. Most of the time, colds get better on their own in 10 days or less. Colds bring on a nasty mix of symptoms that can really wear you down. They can include:
•	Sore throat 
•	Cough 
•	Headache 
•	Stuffy nose
•	Mucus buildup
•	Sneezing 
•	Fatigue 
•	Swollen sinuses
•	Fever (usually low-grade in adults but higher in children)

dialog_nodes.title: Food safety, nutrition, and wellness during COVID-19

values.text: It's advised to eat well cooked food, preferable immediately after cooked. The material itself may or may not be safe but the virus may contaminated it before or after cook. Well cooked food mean a food that is heated to some considerable amount of temperature to some period of time. For example: curry soup, well done steak, deep fried fish.
